div.p: Tracer diffusion coefficients for Li in glasses of albite, orthoclase, and obsidian composition have been determined by a method involving deposition of a thin source on polished glass wafers, anneal under controlled temperature conditions (300-900"C), and ion-microprobe determination of the concentration profile. All results conform to an Arrhenius-type relationship, D = D O exp(-Q/RT), where Q is 23, 17, and 22 kcal mol-1;Dois 0.2, 0.003, and 0.03 cm 2 s -1 for albite and orthoclase glasses, and obsidian respectively. Lithium is thus a fast diffusing ion and behaves similarly to sodium in the same glasses. A mechanism involving jumps of the diffusing ions through oxygen hexagonal rings is suggested by consideration of ionic radii ratio of alkali (H, Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs) ions to the oxygen anions.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Diffusion coefficients of anions and cations in silicate glasses or liquids of geological interest are prerequisite data in the interpretation of the rates at which crystals equilibrate with a magma (e.g. see Bottinga et al. [1 ]). The present study is an outgrowth of earlier work by our group [2][3][4] on alkali metal diffusion in glasses of albite, orthoclase, and obsidian composition. The data for Na, K, Rb, and Ca diffusion were obtained by the conventional radioactive tracer method. Lithium, however, does not have a suitable radioactive isotope, so that a method of obtaining its concentration profile after the diffusion anneal had to be implemented.

Previous experimental work [5,6] on lithium diffusion in glasses has shown that fissures appeared as I.P.G. Contribution No. 267. a result of contraction and provided fast diffusion paths. It was thus clear that this element had to be used in trace amounts before valid data could be obtained.

The ion-microprobe has been used with success in the determination of concentration or isotope ratio profiles (e.g. see Colby [7] and McHugh [8] and has recently been specifically applied to diffusion problems of geological interest [9][10][11][12]. In addition, it affords a high sensitivity for lithium analysis. The analytical method described below is a direct result of these technological developments. [4]. Because of the relatively high diffusion coefficients the concentration profiles were spread over hundreds to thousands of microns. Therefore, direct application of the crater erosion technique under the primary beam of an ion-microprobe [7,8] for the analysis of the resulting profile was not practical.

div.p: After the diffusion anneals the samples were mounted with epoxy resin in a metal ring, and polished perpendicular to the original tracer surface. A thin gold film or grid was deposited on the polished surface by vacuum evaporation.

The lithium concentration profiles were obtained with a CAMECA SMI 300 ion-microprobe. The samples are placed in the holder so that the direction of sample movement is perpendicular to the tracer surface. The secondary ion current for 7Li + ions is then continuously monitored with a potentiometric recorder while moving the sample at a constant speed. div.head: Discussion
div.p: The overall linearity of the log D vs. 1/T plots (Fig. 2) indicate that a single diffusion process for Li is operative in the temperature range studied. The diffusion rates obtained for the three glass compositions are on the same order of magnitude as for Na in M20-A1203-SiO2 glasses [2,3,4,15] but differ substantially from K, Rb, and Cs behavior in being markedly faster. The rates are, however, considerably smaller than could have been predicted from Winchell's [16] suggestion that activation energies are linearly related to ionic radii. Fig. 3 presents such a diagram where our data [3,4], and this study) for Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs in the three glass compositions are summarized.

We have chosen to attribute to those ions a coordination number equal to that found in most silicate compounds. The effective ionic sizes of the large cations (e.g. Rb and Cs mostly) in the glasses may, however, differ noticeably from the chosen value. It is readily seen that activation energies vs. ionic radius of the alkali ions follow two major trends. Ions larger than K ÷ have rapidly increasing activation energies, whereas those smaller than K ÷ show a relative constancy (15-23 kcal tool-l). These trends will not be affected in their general appearance by chosing different coordination numbers. Noteworthy also is the fact that H (H~O?) diffusion in silicate glasses is also characterized by an activation energy on the order of 20 kcal mo1-1 [17]. These features suggest the following as regards to the mechanism of diffusion• The glass structure may be approximated by an oxygen close packed framework with a relatively large number of anion "vacancies"• In such a structure the anion vacancy is surrounded by a hexagonal ring of anions• The jump through the ring of alkali ions having the same size as oxygen or smaller will therefore not require the energy corresponding to the deformation of the ring but only an electrostatic component which we take to be equal to about 20 kcal mo1-1. Larger ions like Rb + or Cs ÷ will require an additional deformational energy term increasing rapidly with the size contrast between anions and cations. This is in keeping with the smaller activation energies found for the more loosely packed ortho-clase glass. Additional support for such a mechanism is found in the data of Hofmann and Magaritz [18] who show that ionic size for divalent cations is ineffective in modifying the activation energy (approximately 40 kcal mo1-1 for Ca 2÷ and Sr 2÷ which are smaller than O 2-, and Ba 2÷ which is the same size as 02-for coordination numbers smaller than twelve). The higher activation energy for the divalent cations would be due to stronger electrostatic effects. We believe that there is a strong case for similar cation diffusion mechanisms in glasses.

Although small systematic differences in the behavior of I3, Na, and K in the glasses seem to occur a detailed mechanistic account will not be attempted here. Similarly, the data on diffusion for the other cations at hand do not warrant such an attempt more involved than is presented above• The data do, how-ever, give some experimental evidence that diffusion controlled chemical zonation in plagioclase phenocrysts (e.g. [1,19]) is not due to slow alkali mobility. Control must be effected by slower-moving ions and/or melt-crystal interface equilibria.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: We have shown that (1) the ion-microprobe is a sensitive tool for the study of lithium diffusion profiles, and (2) alkali diffusion in silicate glasses (melts?) of geological interest is dominated by processes showing relatively small activation energies and, thus, rapid rates to low temperatures for ions smaller than oxygen. The rate decreases rapidly for larger ions.
